section.title: SqlSessionTemplate
section.para: SqlSessionTemplate is the heart of MyBatis-Spring. This class is responsible for managing MyBatis SqlSessions, calling MyBatis SQL methods and translating exceptions. It is meant to be a drop-in replacement for SqlSession. SqlSessionTemplate should always be used instead of SqlSession because the base MyBatis session cannot participate in Spring transactions. Switching between the two classes in the same application can cause data integrity issues.

When calling SQL methods, including any method from Mappers returned from getMapper(), SqlSessionTemplate will ensure that the SqlSession used is the one associated with the current Spring transaction. In addition, it manages the session life-cycle, including closing, committing or rolling back as necessary.

It is usually not necessary to create or use a SqlSessionTemplate directly. In most cases, MapperFactoryBean, which uses a template internally, will be all that is needed. When access to an SqlSessionTemplate is needed, it can be created using an SqlSessionFactory as a constructor argument.
SqlSessionTemplate sessionTemplate = new SqlSessionTemplate(sqlSessionFactory); Similarly, the template could be configured in a Spring XML file.

Note that the execute method can also accept a ExecutorType parameter. This can be used if the desired execution method differs from the default set for the SqlSessionFactory. This will mostly be useful for performing batch SQL queries using ExecutorType.BATCH. The only caveat to this form of the method is that there cannot be an existing transaction running with a different ExecutorType when this method is called. Either ensure that calls to execute(SqlSessionCallback, ExecutorType) run in a separate transaction, with PROPAGATION_REQUIRES_NEW or with completely outside of a transaction.

section.title: SqlSessionDaoSupport
section.para: SqlSessionDaoSupport is configured similarly to MapperFactoryBean. It requires either an sqlSessionFactory or an sqlSessionTemplate property to be set. These can be set explicitly or autowired by Spring. If both properties are set, the SqlSessionFactory is ignored.

Assuming a class UserMapperImpl that subclasses SqlSessionDaoSupport, it can be configured in Spring like the following:
<bean id="userMapperImpl" class="sample.UserMapperImpl"> <!-- SqlSessionFactory property is autowired --> </bean>
